chapter.title: Sage: Basics

li.p: Gain familiarity with Sage cells and the CoCalc environment.
Learn some elementary Sage/Python syntax and commands.

chapter.introduction:
> Special Instructions
This is not a manual for using Sage to solve mathematical problems. Consult the excellent Sage for Undergraduates by Gregory Bard.
We will be making extensive use of CoCalc throughout the semester, so your very first task is to set up an accountThis is discussed in the course syllabus for Math 3380 as well as on the first day of class.. While most examples of Sage or Python code will be emdedded in Sage cells within the text, it is important that you are logged into CoCalc and actively typing code examples and working along with exercises as we progress - especially if you are using an offline copy of the book!
We're going to extensively discuss actual code in these notes, so let's determine some conventions.
Text which appears like this will hereafter always be one of several things:
a Sage or Python command,
a filename, or
a URL or email address.

conclusion.p: This text was originally written with the intent that students would write code in Python 3.5 using the IDLE environment. This is a perfectly valid plan, but Sage and SageMathCloud use Python 2.7, which differs from Python 3.5 in ways more important than just syntax. Some references to code from Python 3.5 remain scattered throughout the text. When they all have absolutely been eradicated, this warning will be removed.
